article_title: Five Best: Mary Gordon on teachers
article_text:
The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie

By Muriel Spark (1961)

1. It would be churlish to be ungrateful for Maggie Smith's unforgettable film performance as Miss Jean Brodie, but the book has complications and subtleties that the movie can't approach. It is concerned with the dangers and seductions—and possibilities—of glamour, of a charismatic personality. Like all good teachers, Miss Brodie offers her students a larger world, more highly colored and heroic than the respectable one for which they are meant to be prepared. But she...

twitter.description: The author of "The Liar's Wife: Four Novellas" recommends "The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie," by Muriel Spark; "Pnin," by Vladimir Nabokov; "June Recital," by Eudora Welty; "Villette," by Charlotte Brontë; and "The Land of Spices," by Kate O'Brien.
twitter.title: Mary Gordon

article_summary:
Like all good teachers, Miss Brodie offers her students a larger world, more highly colored and heroic than the respectable one for which they are meant to be prepared.
The Prime of Miss Jean BrodieBy Muriel Spark (1961)1.
It would be churlish to be ungrateful for Maggie Smith's unforgettable film performance as Miss Jean Brodie, but the book has complications and subtleties that the movie can't approach.
It is concerned with the dangers and seductions—and possibilities—of glamour, of a charismatic personality.
